H0.text: Acid rain is formed when nitrogen and sulfur oxides in air dissolve in rain.

H1.text: Carbon rain is formed when nitrogen and sulfur oxides in air dissolve in rain.

H2.text: Dioxide rain is formed when nitrogen and sulfur oxides in the air dissolve in rain.

H3.text: Acid snow forms when nitrogen and sulfur oxides in air dissolve in rain.

A4.text: The principal cause of acid rain is sulfur and nitrogen compounds from human sources, such as electricity generation, animal agriculture, factories, and motor vehicles.

A5.text: Wet deposition of acids occurs when any form of precipitation (rain, snow, and so on) removes acids from the atmosphere and delivers it to the Earth's surface.
